comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Cardinal James Gibbons (1834-1921), the second American to become a cardinal in the Roman Catholic Church; encouraged American Catholics to support the labor movement, saying "It is the right of laboring classes to protect themselves, and the duty of the whole people to find a remedy against avarice, oppression, and corruption." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Gibbons

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3a47937 for an 1886 photo of the cardinal.

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks, penny, for the information about Cardinal Gibbons.  I'd like to keep the discussion going.  Do you have any idea what he might have been doing in Milwaukee?

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: According to the NYTimes, Gibbons attended a convention in Milwaukee in August 1913 when the American Federation of Catholic Societies met there, and he performed the formal opening ceremonies at St. John's Cathedral.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Here is a working link to the New York Times story of August 11, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940DEFDF123FE633A...

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Whoops--thanks Wystan.  I'll be more careful next time.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: A group of delegates to the convention of the American Federation of Catholic Societies, in Milwaukee, August, 1913: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4036735493/in/p...

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Wystan and pennylrichardsca: Thanks for the additional information.  We'll add the date and event to our source data next time we update.
